contents.params: Cells can be genetically-directed to interact with other cells. Here we examine some applications of engineered microbial interactions.

The E. coli species is composed of many thousands of variant strains, some of which are pathogenic.  In this study by Sansonetti and coworkers, they investigate what is the minimal set of genes needed to convert the laboratory K12 strain into a strain functionally equivalent to Shigella flexneri.  Shigella is E. coli's closest cousin on the phylogenetic tree, but from a clinical perspective the two organisms are quite different.

Bacteria are known to frequently participate in horizontal gene transfer.  As a result, genes related by a process are often clustered in the genome which enables them to more easily be transferred as a functional set.  We can also use synthesis to intentionally move a set of related genes.  One general question is, how often do such transfer experiments work, and where do they go awry?

Live vaccines are one of the more advanced applications of engineered bacteria.In this study, Splitter and coworkers engineer laboratory strains of E. coli as a vaccine vector against the intracellular pathogenic bacterium Brucella.

A common refrain in the area of therapeutic bacteria is the problem of strong immune responses to the bacteria.  Though there aren't many engineering studies involving the alteration of these properties, there are a few.In this study by Species and coworkers, the authors demonstrate that the outer membrane lipid can be altered to mimic the structure present in another bacterium, Chlamydia.
